name: OM
Application: to find mental clarity and gain self realization
Benefits: induce relexation, build pleasant vibrations in the body, remove psychological disturbances, and make you feel connected to the source
Significance: According to yoga scriptures, Om is the most basic, the most primordial, and the most complete sound that there is. Om consists of sounds aaa, ooo, and mmmâ€”three fundamental units of human speech, which form the basis of almost all spoken words across all human languages. In a profoundly relaxed and deep meditative state, the human vocal organ spontaneously generates a vibratory sound similar to Om. All religions have a basic mantra that more or less resembles Om. In Hinduism, Om is so revered and valued that they say the vedas manifested from the mouth of Brahma the creator but Brahma himself manifested from Om! In Bhagavad Gita Krishna prescribes to the seekers of Moksha that they should commence all activities with (intrnal) recitation of Om. The highly celebrated Mandukya Upanishad equates the four states of consciousness (waking, dreaming, sleeping, and samadhi) with the four parts of Om (a, o, m, and the silence) and claims that grasping the true meaning of Om unravels the entire mystery of consciousness.
How to chant: This mantra should be chanted at the beginning and the end of a meditation or yoga session. When pronoucing Om the sound A should last for 2 units of time, O for 6 units, M for 1 unit, and the silence for 6 units of time. Doing a daily mala of Om (108 repitions) is a simple yet powerful concentration practice. Relecting on the meaning of Om while reciting it first audibly and then mentally is a popular meditation technique as recommended in the Yoga Sutras of Patanjali.
mantraenglish:
Om!
The word. The sound. The vibration. The name of the source.

name: Gayatri Mantra
Application: to sharpen the intellect and to seek illumination
Benefits: strengthen the intellect, illuminate the mind, and grant self-knowledge
Significance: This highly revered mantra invokes Surya, the sun god, in the form of Savitr, which is the vedic reference for the sun when its between sunset (post-dusk) and sunrise (pre-dawn). The Gayatri mantra together with the Mahamrityunjaya mantra are considered the most special and thought to embed all essential mantra shakti. This mantra is a must before any knowledge seeking endeavor. Traditionally, this mantra was given by the teacher to the pupil as part of the threading ceremony right before starting the formal education, like a right of passage.
How to chant: This mantra can be chanted anywhere and anytime, but it will incur the highest benefit when chanted during the early morning period (bramha muhurta). For the beginners, the correct vedic pronunciation in the intended rhythm may provide a noticeably deeper inner experience. Meditators should chant it at the beginning of their meditation session. This mantra is often used for Purashcharan (the practice of chanting the mantra 100008 times under the guidance of a spiritual guide).

name: Omkara Mantra
Application: to seek devotion and to ask Lord Shiva to grant the bliss of Yoga
Benefits: strengthen the resolve for yoga practice and increase mental peace and clairty
Significance: Vishnu is considered the lord of Yoga (Yogeshwara) whereas Shiva is considered the lord of Yogis (Yogishwara). This peaceful mantra is a popular invocation recited daily by generations of yoga practitioners to seek Lord Shiva's blessing to attain ultimate success in yoga, which is Moksha. Shiva is the lord of rhythm and vibration and Om is the ultimate vibration, therefore Shiva is also referred to as Omkara. This mantra emphasizes the wholistic nature of true Yogic pursuit, in which the desires are not to be suppressed rather properly understood and fullfilled so the seeker can progress quicker and steadier on the spiritual path.
How to chant: This mantra should be recited at the beginning of daily yoga practice. Not only knowing the words and the pronunciation but also the meaning and the significance is crucial to make this a remarkably powerful invocation.
